Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2015 08:40AM SchoolCounselor wrote: Hi ladies, I am so scared right now. I have been having severe knee pain for about 6 weeks now that has gotten progressively worse. A month ago I saw an orthopedic who did an X-ray and MRI of my knees and found some fluid but mild arthritis. I started PT 3 weeks ago. Now the pain is excruciating and the PT says it's Unusual for there to be no relief. He suggested I call my MO. I know mets rarely go below the knee, but the pain is horrific. It hurts whe I am sleeping. I walk like I am 90 and I Am 47. I have been on a AI for about a year and had joint pain in the beginning but the pain was not likE this I had an MRI. is it possible for the Cancer to not show up there ? Do I need a bone scan Tha
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2015 11:41PM SchoolCounselor wrote: I feel like I come here so often..... In May I got a PET scan because I was having so much pain in my joints I had a meltdown in my MO's office. I changed AI's from exemestane to Femara. Last week in August I started with a dry cough. Of course my head goes to all kinds of places. Shortness of breath. Pain in my chest. I went to see my primary and he put me on steroids. It has reduced the inflammation in my chest. So no pain, however the cough is really terrible. Non productive and it has me gasping for air. I see the Pulmonologist on Wednesday. I made the appointment myself. My question is can lung mets grow so quickly that a PET scan would miss them? I'm really worried, Thank you.

Posts.Content: May 9, 2015 05:46AM SchoolCounselor wrote: I was here a few weeks ago with significant knee and foot pain. My MO switched me off exemesthane and pit me on femara. He also sent me off to a rheumatologist who did not find anything. He did give me etodolac, lidocaine patches and Voltaren gel. For a blissful week I was without pain. Now it is back with a vengeance. Bone pain in my legs, lower back pain and rib pain. I went to bed at 11pm and have been up since 3am in pain. It is now 5:40am I also have neck pain. I saw my MO April 9th. While my knees are not as bad. My legs and back are keeping me up. When my pain started in March. The orthopedic doctor sent me for an X-ray of my knees and MRI of right knee. Nothing remarkable just some osteoarthritis. I hate being worried, I hate being scared. When do I get my life back? Do I call my MO?. I feel like there is always something. Thoughts? Thank you for your time.

Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2013 08:18PM SchoolCounselor wrote: Great News Travlmom. Good luck to all with surgeries today. I am finding kindness in all areas. Yesterday I dropped off my car with the mechanic and mentioned to him that I have breast cancer and do not want to worry about my car for the next 6 months. HE disappears into the back of the shop and reappears with a book. "Eating Well Through Cancer". Apparently a resident of my town is a national spokes person for cancer and gave him books to pass along to anyone who he encounters to help them. I was so overcome with tears. When I returned to pick up my car, he asked me to go test drive it with him. We went on a 15 minute drive on back roads where he gave me a the best pep talk. I am so overwhelmed by his kindness! Also, it seems the more I clean the dirtier my house becomes!!!! Hope everyone is hanging in there!
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2013 02:13PM SchoolCounselor wrote: Glad to hear from you summergal. Glad you are taking it easy and that everything went well.  I still do not understand how they do not numb you for the dye, this process is barbaric enough, why add to it. Keep us posted on your progress. Take Care
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2013 04:02PM SchoolCounselor wrote: Hi all, Just a quick check in, I an in incredible pain. Prior to surgery, I worked out quite often. Did a lot of push ups, pull ups, Olympic bar chest press so I have very tight muscles. My PS said it was a first for him, the tightnes of my muscles. As a result, I am still on percocet every 4 hours, the have also added flexoral (muscle relaxer). Today he took out one drain and I see him again on Wednesday, perhaps he will take out one more on Wednesday. So the incision looks great he says, and other than the pain, he says I am doing well. I am taking your adivce and not doing too much, but it is so hard to do. I have to remind myself, that the more I do, the longer recovery will be. I hope everyone is doing well
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2013 05:32PM SchoolCounselor wrote: MBLizzy. IT is always great when the pathology report solidifies our decision making. I see the BS today and I am hoping that i walk out of her office with the feeling that I did the right thing as well.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2013 08:38AM SchoolCounselor wrote: Hi ladies. I have had a really rough couple of days. Between the pain of the the TE's and the fever I developed. I have not been in a good place. However, antibiotics are working now, I am of the narcotics and feeling more myself, well as much myself as possible. I am continually haunted by the fact that my life will never be the same, that cancer has taken away my safety and security, but fortunately not my faith. I still have pockets of fluid under my armpits after the drain removal, at first I thought the PS took them out too soon, but judging by the fever I ended up with I am glad he took them when he did. Anyone have an idea how long it will take the body to absorb this? I see the oncologist tomorrow, at first my BS said I would not need chemo, but when the pathology returned, she said due to the size of the cancer and the aggressive nature of it I may need to, so just to ready my mind for it. In reading all the posts I remember those needles to the aereola(SP) with the radioactive isotopes, I thought I would die, I have never experienced pain like that before. I remember asking why that could not be done while I was already under and how barbaric that was. Then a nurse offered me some aromatherapy ate that and the lavender really calmed me down. My brain does not work well under stress I am finding because I wanted to respond to each of you individually, but please know I read every post and I am shring in your pain, sorrows and joy! Oh, I forgot, constipation can be horrific, and colace did nothing for me. I had to have a fleet enema twice and that did the trick, of course the antibiotic now is helping me wonderfully and I am back to normal. I can't believe September is over already....
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2013 05:02AM SchoolCounselor wrote: wow do much is happening here!! Denise Congrats on the wedding, I would feel safest with the ace bandages, there will be a lot of hugging I'm sure and you want those drains secure. Side boob is the bane of my existence, so glad I am not working yet because all clothes look just awful on me. I went to Sloane Kettering for my second opinion today. Sobering, to hear that cancer cells can be in your body for up to 10 years before they are manifested and for her to guarantee that I have cancer cells flying around now is really hard to hear. Also the reality that if I have a recurrence it would most likely not be found early. Yeah. But I loved the honesty so I am waiting for the oncotype test to come back but I am going with chemo and then tamoxiphen for 10 years and then something that starts with an "a" for another 10 years at least. Good to have a plan. In the middle of all this I of course have to keep seeing the PS for refills. How many of you are doing all this while working? Stay strong ladies!!
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2013 08:59AM SchoolCounselor wrote: My dad is a surgeon. It wasn't until he got sick himself - he is dying from stomach cancer and currently on a ventilator- that he realized how flawed some of the instructions he had given to patients. The idea that you could be back at work lifting after a serious procedure is quite unreal to me. If you can take off a week at least. I suggest you do that. You can ask your doctor for a note. Listen to your biody, rushing back to work only prolonged your healing. Also allow your mind to grieve and adjust. We are all so busy being strong all the time.

It seems from BMX with TE to the final exchange it is about 6 months. Is that accurate? Then the nipples come later.... does that mean I have almost a year without complete breasts? I'm not in that good, happy place tonight.....
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2013 11:50AM SchoolCounselor wrote: Thank you ladies for checking in, it keeps me going just knowing everyone is progressing in their journey. Yesterday was my last day at work, very emotional, a colleague of mine's wife is at the tail end of a 1 year journey with breast cancer and he told me just to take it a day at a time. Some days will be really bad and some will be okay. Another colleague is a survivor and this is her fifth year. She just held me and cried. At one point she remarked , "I don't know why I am crying" and I responded, "It's because you now the journey I am about to going through". Then she said something that will stay with me. She said" You will find strength that you never knew you had, when you are at your lowest , you will always find it".....I just thought I would share that...Good Luck ladies....the journey continues...

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2013 10:47PM SchoolCounselor wrote: Wow, I go away for a weekend and all this activity. Welcome all to the the club none of us want to belong to. I can relate so much to what you are all talking about. With regard to pain across your chest, ask the doctor for a muscle relaxant. I used flexarol for a while beyond when i needed pain meds to relax the muscle and then there was no pain. My doctor took out my drain when one was still giving off 40cc a day and I ended up with a fluid build up, I am grateful he did because two days later I spiked a fever and went on antibiotics, he was so happy he had pulled the drains and so was I. He said he had a gut feeling to just do it and 10 days were enough. Today I went out with my family, to the mall, and out to eat, We went straight to buy them shoes, picked up cheese cake and ate. I was ready to go to bed when I got home at 3pm. So worn out a reminder that our bodies have really taken a beating! I have also driven twice. I have a large truck so you need a lot of arm motion to turn the wheel, big mistake the first time, okay the second time. We don't realize how much concentration and reflexes that driving needs until we can't do it. Tomorrow I see the plastic surgeon for my first fill, then I agreed to be in a clinical study about cancer and emotional support for women 45 and under and then I see the oncologist to tell him that I am getting a second opinion. Has anyone had to do that? I just need to know that chemo is warranted for my cancer and the type is the right one. I also heard that new cancer studies are suggesting that taking Tamoxiphen for 10 years as opposed to 5 years has better outcomes. Hope we all have a good week!

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2013 06:32PM SchoolCounselor wrote: my oncotype score was 12 and both of the MO's I saw recommended chemo, I was doing it anyway. There is also a clinical study going on called Taylor x I believe, that is looking at the prognosis and chemo benefit for those with a score between 11 and 25. The score meant I had an 8% chance of reoccurrence in the next 10 years. I'm only 44 and that was not good enough for me. Cheryl, this is a hard decision and only you can decide what is right for you (((((hugs)))))

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2013 08:02PM SchoolCounselor wrote: Hi KeeM, you are my surgery day twin! I know the 16th is listed, but it is the 17th. Also I also just had an infection and needed antibiotics prior to surgery. Thee doctors did not want me to have any infections in my body especially since I was getting TE's. I have IDC and DCIS in one breast and LCIS in the other, like you. I really do not have nay choice, especially as the DCIS did not show up in any of the screenings, Mammo and ultrasound last month and MRI in March. Today I went to do my hair and some girlfriends and I are having a party tonight. Tomorrow I am going to do my nails and get a foot massage. I am trying to fill up the days so I don't think too much. I also brought a body cast to do a mold of my breasts, saw the idea on the internet not sure what I will do with it, but I needed to do something. StacieRae interesting that you are doing a BMX awake, my BS said the BMX for me will take 4 hours alone. I am also curious to hear from those who have done this as well. Take Care all!

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2013 06:44PM SchoolCounselor wrote: Hi Ladies, I just wanted to check in. My surgery was on Tuesday and it went well. I stayed in the hospital until Friday evening and was discharged with four drains. Apart from a bad run in with a nurse, which I reported to her manager and hospital administration, everyone was lovely. There was a tremendous anoint of pain. In part, because I worked out precious to surgery, did a lot of push ups and pull ups, so my muscles were very tight in my chest. They will not start the expansion until three weeks from now, I waant my 40DD back! I got the pathology back and they got all of the cancer, so I am Happy about that. I also arranged for the visiting nurse to come and change the drains for me. Still really woozy. I am taking percoset, colace,an antibiotic and flexoral (SP). This typing is taking a lot out of me. Talk to you soon...

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2013 07:14PM SchoolCounselor wrote: Sandra, He was glad he pulled it because drains can be an entrance into the body for infection which is one of the reasons doctors do not want to leave them in for too long.. My understanding is seroma's are going to happen and the body will reabsorb the fluid. The BS and the oncologist concur. I just wished mine was not a large on the left side as the right side. Please never hesitate to ask questions, I have learned a lot from ladies here that have informed my conversations with my doctors. I welcome them!
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2013 08:37PM SchoolCounselor wrote: Bella, I am wearing a fruit of the loom bra with front closure, it is just more comfortable, I have a lot of skin after my bmx because I was a DD and want to get as close to my original size as possible. The deal with recurrence as I understand it is this: My cancer was found because I was doing the MRI, US and Mammo as I was supposed to. Going forward with no breast tissue those scans will no longer be necessary...other than the annual MRI checking the implants, so if a cancer was to reoccur it would be elsewhere and would probably not be picked up until it gave some physical sign.Because there is no cancer in my lymph nodes, apparently does not mean i do not have cells in my body. Our bodies usually destroy theses cells but for whatever reason, it did not and I got cancer. I don't mean to frighten anyone, but I wanted her to be straight with me. Because of my age, 44 and all my other markers, they recommend the Taxotere chemo for me. 4 treatments over 12 weeks. Cancer and cancer treatments are very individual, chemo will add additional 2% difference for me with regard to reocurrence and I am already in single digits, but to me that's a big deal. I just don't want to ever think there was something that I could have done and did not and that is why I went to Memorial Sloane Kettering Hospital for the second opinion which was the same recommendation from my oncologist. Again this was just my recommendation. I hope this clarify's this more for you.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2013 10:44PM SchoolCounselor wrote: The oncotype test result is pending so I don't have the results yet,however both doctors stated that that would not be the final decision maker in my treatment, just another data point. but given the tumor size grade and my history prior to this cancer-- 5 biopsies within the last 2 years, with mostly atypia, my age 44 and overall health. Both doctors felt that a "light chemo" would help reduce my risk of reocurrence. That's about it. To some people 2% is not a big deal, to me and fortunately my doctors it is.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2013 12:34AM SchoolCounselor wrote: They're still doing the test and I will get the decision, so yes and no. I really am at peace with my decision...also the people who participated in the oncotype clinical trial according to both doctors are really not representative of my age or race. So it is important for them and me to take that into account when making decisions about my treatment. You're so right these are absolutely tough decisions and I don't see chemo as something to be afraid of although I am certainly not looking forward to it. A few years ago I was going into spontaneous anaphylaxis and ending up in the ER for about 6 months almost dying each time, that was scary and so is this but in different way. WE will all make a million different decisions and they will all be right for each of us.
